pr.title: ⚡ Bolt: Optimize cat lookup with a memoized Map
pr.body:
💡 What: This change introduces a memoized `Map` of cats (`catsMap`) into the `CatsContext`. The `use-feeding` hook was then refactored to use this map for an efficient O(1) lookup, replacing the previous O(n) `Array.prototype.find()` call.

🎯 Why: The previous implementation used `cats.find()` inside a `useMemo` hook, which would re-run an O(n) search whenever the `cats` array or `catId` changed. For a large number of cats, this could lead to noticeable performance degradation. Using a `Map` provides a near-instant lookup, making the component more scalable and efficient.

📊 Impact: This optimization changes the cat lookup complexity from O(n) to O(1). This will result in faster rendering of components that use the `useFeeding` hook, with the benefit increasing as the number of cats in the application grows.

🔬 Measurement: The performance improvement can be verified by profiling the application with a large number of cats. The render time for components using the `useFeeding` hook should be significantly reduced, and the profiler should show that the expensive `find` operation has been eliminated.

---

pr.title: ⚡ Bolt: Optimize useSelectUpcomingFeedings hook and fix bug
pr.body:
### 💡 What
This change refactors the `useSelectUpcomingFeedings` hook in `lib/context/FeedingContext.tsx` to be more performant and correct.

### 🎯 Why
The original implementation had two issues:
1.  **Performance:** It was re-sorting an already sorted list of feeding logs on every render, an unnecessary `O(L log L)` operation.
2.  **Bug:** It was sorting the logs in ascending order, causing it to select the *oldest* feeding log for each cat instead of the most recent one.

### 📊 Impact
-   **Performance:** The hook's complexity is reduced from `O(L log L)` to `O(L)`, making it significantly faster, especially for users with a long feeding history.
-   **Correctness:** The hook now correctly identifies the most recent feeding, fixing the underlying bug.

### 🔬 Measurement
The performance improvement can be verified by profiling the `useSelectUpcomingFeedings` hook before and after the change. The functional correctness can be verified by observing that the upcoming feedings are calculated based on the last recorded feeding, not the first.

---

pr.title: ⚡ Bolt: Optimize memoize utility for fewer lookups
pr.body:
### 💡 What
This change optimizes the `memoize` utility by reducing two map lookups into a single one.

### 🎯 Why
The previous implementation performed a `cache.has(key)` check followed by a `cache.get(key)` call. This is an unnecessary double lookup. By using a single `cache.get(key)` and checking if the result is `undefined`, we achieve the same outcome with half the lookups, making the function more efficient.

### 📊 Impact
- Reduces map lookups in the `memoize` function by 50% on cache hits.
- Improves the performance of all memoized functions throughout the application.

### 🔬 Measurement
The improvement can be verified by inspecting the code in `lib/utils/cache.ts`. The number of lookups is reduced from two to one, which is a clear performance win.

---

pr.title: ⚡ Bolt: Optimize upcoming feedings hook
pr.body:
**💡 What:** This change optimizes the `useSelectUpcomingFeedings` hook in `lib/context/FeedingContext.tsx` by removing an unnecessary sort operation.

**🎯 Why:** The hook was sorting the `householdLogs` array on every render, which is an inefficient O(L log L) operation. This was causing performance degradation, especially for users with a large number of feeding logs. Additionally, the previous implementation had a bug where it was using the oldest log instead of the newest.

**📊 Impact:** This optimization reduces the complexity of the hook from O(L log L) to O(L), resulting in a significant performance improvement. It also fixes a bug, ensuring the correct (newest) feeding log is used.

**🔬 Measurement:** The performance improvement can be verified by profiling the component that uses this hook before and after the change. A noticeable reduction in rendering time should be observed, especially with a large dataset of feeding logs.

---

pr.title: 🎨 Palette: Add Loading State to Cat Deletion Dialog
pr.body:
This PR improves the user experience of deleting a cat by adding a loading state to the confirmation dialog.

**💡 What:**
- Added an `isDeleting` prop to the `CatCard` component.
- The delete confirmation dialog now shows a loading spinner and disables the "Excluir" and "Cancelar" buttons when `isDeleting` is true.
- Updated the `CatsPage` component to manage the `isDeleting` state, ensuring only the correct cat card shows the loading indicator.

**🎯 Why:**
Previously, there was no visual feedback after a user confirmed they wanted to delete a cat. This could lead to confusion and multiple clicks, potentially causing errors. The new loading state makes it clear that the application is processing the request.

**♿ Accessibility:**
- The disabled state on the buttons prevents keyboard and screen reader interaction during the loading process, which is the correct behavior for a modal dialog in a loading state.

---

pr.title: ⚡ Bolt: Optimize useSelectUpcomingFeedings hook by removing redundant sort
pr.body:
### 💡 What
This change optimizes the `useSelectUpcomingFeedings` hook in `lib/context/FeedingContext.tsx` by removing a redundant and incorrect sorting operation.

### 🎯 Why
The previous implementation re-sorted an already sorted list of feeding logs on every render, which was an unnecessary `O(L log L)` operation. It also sorted the logs in ascending order, causing it to select the oldest feeding log instead of the most recent one.

### 📊 Impact
- **Performance:** Improves the hook's performance from `O(L log L)` to `O(L)`.
- **Bug Fix:** Corrects a bug that caused the wrong feeding log to be selected.

### 🔬 Measurement
The improvement can be verified by observing the reduced computation time in the `useSelectUpcomingFeedings` hook when dealing with a large number of feeding logs. The corrected behavior can be confirmed by ensuring the most recent feeding is always used for calculations.

---

pr.title: ⚡ Bolt: Optimize useSelectUpcomingFeedings hook
pr.body:
### 💡 What
- Refactored the `useSelectUpcomingFeedings` hook in `lib/context/FeedingContext.tsx`.
- Replaced an inefficient `O(L log L)` sorting operation with a more performant `O(L)` single-pass approach.
- This change also fixes a bug where the oldest feeding log was being selected instead of the most recent one.

### 🎯 Why
- The previous implementation unnecessarily re-sorted an already sorted array of feeding logs on every render.
- This caused a performance bottleneck, especially with a large number of feeding logs.
- The sorting logic was also incorrect, leading to a bug in the application's logic.

### 📊 Impact
- Improves the performance of the `useSelectUpcomingFeedings` hook from `O(L log L)` to `O(L)`.
- Reduces unnecessary computation and improves the overall responsiveness of the UI components that use this hook.
- Fixes a bug that caused incorrect upcoming feeding calculations.

### 🔬 Measurement
- The performance improvement can be verified by measuring the execution time of the `useSelectUpcomingFeedings` hook before and after the change, especially with a large dataset of feeding logs.
- The bug fix can be verified by observing that the upcoming feeding times are now calculated based on the most recent feeding for each cat, not the oldest.

pr.title: 🎨 Palette: Improve Spinner Accessibility
pr.body:
💡 **What:** Added `role="status"` and a visually hidden "Carregando..." (Loading...) message to the `Spinner` component.

🎯 **Why:** Previously, the loading spinner was invisible to screen readers when used without an accompanying text label. This meant that visually impaired users would not know that content was loading, leading to a confusing experience.

📸 **Before/After:**
*   **Before:** Screen readers would not announce anything when the spinner appeared.
*   **After:** Screen readers will now announce "Carregando..." when the spinner is active, providing crucial feedback to the user.
A screenshot was captured during verification showing the spinner component in its loading state on the login page.

♿ **Accessibility:** This change directly addresses a critical accessibility issue by making the loading state perceptible to screen reader users, ensuring they receive the same information as sighted users.

---

pr.title: ⚡ Bolt: Optimize upcoming feedings selector
pr.body:
This pull request optimizes the `useSelectUpcomingFeedings` hook by replacing an inefficient O(L log L) re-sort with a more performant O(L) single-pass loop. This change leverages the existing descending sort order of the feeding logs to find the most recent feeding for each cat, significantly improving performance and fixing a bug where the oldest log was being selected instead of the most recent one.

pr.title: ⚡ Bolt: Memoize FeedingLogItem to reduce re-renders
pr.body:
This change introduces a significant performance improvement to the `FeedingsPage` by memoizing the `FeedingLogItem` component. This prevents unnecessary re-renders when filtering or sorting the list, resulting in a smoother and more responsive user interface. The implementation follows best practices by using `React.memo` for the component and `useCallback` for the event handlers passed as props. Additionally, a minor functional regression identified during code review has been addressed by restoring a missing hyperlink.

pr.body:

It also improves accessibility by hiding the original content from screen readers during the loading state.

performed_via_github_app.name: Netlify
performed_via_github_app.description:
Publish incredibly high performance websites and applications right from GitHub. The Netlify platform connects your repositories to an all-in-one workflow for global CDN deployment, continuous integration, and automatic (and free) HTTPS. Each time you commit changes, Netlify builds your site, prerenders markup, and optimizes assets on dedicated build infrastructure. Easily create an entirely automated workflows for your web applications

## Features

### Push your site live, directly from GitHub
Deploy your site to an ultra-redundant global CDN that’s purpose built for serving pages and assets quickly and consistently.

### Automate deployment
Netlify’s built-in Continuous Deployment automatically runs your build commands and deploys the result whenever you push to your Git repository.

### Add a custom domain
Purchase domains and manage DNS zones and records right inside of Netlify.

### HTTPS is automatic
Your site will automatically be secured with a free TLS certificate from Let’s Encrypt.

### Deploy Previews
Netlify’s Deploy Previews streamlined your workflow by giving you a unique, permanent URL to check what your changes will be like in production whenever you submit a pull request.

### And a lot more!
Netlify includes solutions for forms, identity, and even custom functions powered by AWS Lambda. And all this functionality can be configured directly in your repo.

pr.title: 🎨 Palette: Make CardTitle a Semantic Heading
pr.body:
This submission updates the `CardTitle` component to use a semantic `h3` element, improving accessibility for screen reader users. The change is confined to `components/ui/card.tsx` and has no visual impact. I also addressed code review feedback by removing an unnecessary log file from the commit.

---
*PR created automatically by Jules for task [10317578883459769735](https://jules.google.com/task/10317578883459769735) started by @mauriciobc*

files.patch:
@@ -30,10 +30,10 @@ const CardHeader = React.forwardRef<
 CardHeader.displayName = "CardHeader"
 
 const CardTitle = React.forwardRef<
-  HTMLDivElement,
-  React.HTMLAttributes<HTMLDivElement>
+  HTMLHeadingElement,
+  React.HTMLAttributes<HTMLHeadingElement>
 >(({ className, ...props }, ref) => (
-  <div
+  <h3
     ref={ref}
     className={cn(
       "text-2xl font-semibold leading-none tracking-tight",

performed_via_github_app.name: Netlify
performed_via_github_app.description:
Publish incredibly high performance websites and applications right from GitHub. The Netlify platform connects your repositories to an all-in-one workflow for global CDN deployment, continuous integration, and automatic (and free) HTTPS. Each time you commit changes, Netlify builds your site, prerenders markup, and optimizes assets on dedicated build infrastructure. Easily create an entirely automated workflows for your web applications

## Features

### Push your site live, directly from GitHub
Deploy your site to an ultra-redundant global CDN that’s purpose built for serving pages and assets quickly and consistently.

### Automate deployment
Netlify’s built-in Continuous Deployment automatically runs your build commands and deploys the result whenever you push to your Git repository.

### Add a custom domain
Purchase domains and manage DNS zones and records right inside of Netlify.

### HTTPS is automatic
Your site will automatically be secured with a free TLS certificate from Let’s Encrypt.

### Deploy Previews
Netlify’s Deploy Previews streamlined your workflow by giving you a unique, permanent URL to check what your changes will be like in production whenever you submit a pull request.

### And a lot more!
Netlify includes solutions for forms, identity, and even custom functions powered by AWS Lambda. And all this functionality can be configured directly in your repo.

pr.title: 🎨 Palette: Improve Login Page Accessibility
pr.body:
### 💡 What
This change enhances the accessibility of the password input field on the login page.

### 🎯 Why
The icon-only button for toggling password visibility lacked a text alternative for screen readers and a visible focus state for keyboard users. This made it difficult for users with visual impairments or those who rely on keyboard navigation to use this feature.

### 📸 Before/After
**Before:** The toggle button had no ARIA label and no focus ring.
**After:** The toggle button now has a dynamic ARIA label and a clear focus ring, as shown in the verification screenshot.

### ♿ Accessibility
-   **ARIA Label:** Added a dynamic `aria-label` that changes to "Mostrar senha" (Show password) or "Ocultar senha" (Hide password).
-   **Focus State:** Added `focus-visible:ring-2 focus-visible:ring-ring` classes to make the keyboard focus state clear and consistent with the site's design system.

---

pr.title: ⚡ Bolt: Optimize log grouping from O(n^2) to O(n)
pr.body:
### 💡 What
Refactored the `groupLogsByDate` utility function to eliminate a nested-loop-like performance anti-pattern. The new implementation first groups all feeding logs by date and then sorts each daily group individually.

### 🎯 Why
The original function sorted the array of logs on every single iteration of its `reduce` loop. For pages with many logs, this resulted in O(n^2) complexity, causing noticeable slowdowns and inefficient processing.

### 📊 Impact
This change improves the grouping algorithm's time complexity from O(n^2) to a much more efficient O(n log k), where 'n' is the total number of logs and 'k' is the maximum number of logs on any single day. This will result in faster rendering of the feeding history page, especially for users with extensive log histories.

### 🔬 Measurement
The performance improvement can be verified by profiling the `FeedingsPage` component in a development environment with a large number of `feedingLogs`. The execution time of the `groupLogsByDate` function will be significantly lower.

---

pr.title: ⚡ Bolt: Optimize `groupLogsByDate` to O(n)
pr.body:
*   **💡 What:** Refactored the `groupLogsByDate` utility function.
*   **🎯 Why:** The original implementation used an inefficient O(n^2) algorithm by sorting an array within a `reduce` loop. This could cause significant slowdowns when processing a large number of feeding logs.
*   **📊 Impact:** The new implementation reduces the complexity to O(n log k) (where n is the total number of logs and k is the number of logs per day), which is practically O(n) for this use case. It first groups all logs by date in a single pass and then sorts each small daily group once. This will make the "Feedings" page load noticeably faster for users with extensive history.
*   **🔬 Measurement:** To verify, inspect the `lib/utils/feedingUtils.ts` file. The code now clearly separates the grouping (`reduce`) and sorting (`for...in` loop with `sort`) operations, avoiding the nested, repeated sorting. Performance can be benchmarked by generating a large number of logs and measuring the execution time of this function before and after the change.

---

pr.title: 🎨 Palette: Add ARIA label to password visibility button
pr.body:
This pull request adds a dynamic `aria-label` to the show/hide password button on the login page, making it accessible to screen reader users. The label's text updates to reflect the button's current function, providing a more inclusive user experience.

---

pr.title: ⚡ Bolt: Optimize `groupLogsByDate` to avoid O(n^2) complexity
pr.body:
### 💡 What
This change refactors the `groupLogsByDate` utility function to improve its performance. The original implementation sorted an array on every iteration of a `reduce` loop, which has been replaced with a more efficient approach that first groups the logs and then sorts each group once.

### 🎯 Why
The original implementation had a time complexity of O(n^2) in the worst-case scenario (many logs on the same day). This can cause noticeable slowdowns on the frontend when processing a large number of feeding logs. The new implementation reduces the complexity to O(n log n), ensuring the function remains performant even with large datasets.

### 📊 Impact
This optimization significantly reduces the execution time for grouping and sorting feeding logs. For a large number of logs (e.g., thousands), this can reduce the processing time from seconds to milliseconds, leading to a faster and more responsive UI.

### 🔬 Measurement
The performance improvement can be verified by creating a large array of `FeedingLog` objects and measuring the execution time of the `groupLogsByDate` function before and after the change.

---

pr.title: ⚡ Bolt: Optimize log grouping logic
pr.body:
### 💡 What
This change refactors the `groupLogsByDate` function in `lib/utils/feedingUtils.ts` to be more performant.

### 🎯 Why
The original implementation had an inefficient algorithm that sorted an array on every iteration of a `reduce` loop. For a large number of logs on the same day, this could approach O(n^2) complexity, causing slowdowns.

### 📊 Impact
The new implementation uses a two-pass approach (group then sort), which significantly reduces the computational complexity to be closer to O(n log n). This will result in faster grouping of feeding logs, especially for users with extensive log histories.

### 🔬 Measurement
The performance improvement can be verified by benchmarking the `groupLogsByDate` function with a large array of `FeedingLog` objects, particularly with many logs sharing the same date. The optimized function will execute significantly faster.

---

👋 Jules, reporting for duty! I'm here to lend a hand with this pull request.

When you start a review, I'll add a 👀 emoji to each comment to let you know I've read it. I'll focus on feedback directed at me and will do my best to stay out of conversations between you and other bots or reviewers to keep the noise down.

I'll push a commit with your requested changes shortly after. Please note there might be a delay between these steps, but rest assured I'm on the job!

For more direct control, you can switch me to **Reactive Mode**. When this mode is on, I will only act on comments where you specifically mention me with `@jules`. You can find this option in the **Pull Request** section of your [global Jules UI settings](https://jules.google.com/settings). You can always switch back!

---
*_For security, I will only act on instructions from the user who triggered this task._*

New to Jules? Learn more at [jules.google/docs](https://jules.google/docs).

performed_via_github_app.name: Netlify
performed_via_github_app.description:
Publish incredibly high performance websites and applications right from GitHub. The Netlify platform connects your repositories to an all-in-one workflow for global CDN deployment, continuous integration, and automatic (and free) HTTPS. Each time you commit changes, Netlify builds your site, prerenders markup, and optimizes assets on dedicated build infrastructure. Easily create an entirely automated workflows for your web applications

## Features

### Push your site live, directly from GitHub
Deploy your site to an ultra-redundant global CDN that’s purpose built for serving pages and assets quickly and consistently.

### Automate deployment
Netlify’s built-in Continuous Deployment automatically runs your build commands and deploys the result whenever you push to your Git repository.

### Add a custom domain
Purchase domains and manage DNS zones and records right inside of Netlify.

### HTTPS is automatic
Your site will automatically be secured with a free TLS certificate from Let’s Encrypt.

### Deploy Previews
Netlify’s Deploy Previews streamlined your workflow by giving you a unique, permanent URL to check what your changes will be like in production whenever you submit a pull request.

### And a lot more!
Netlify includes solutions for forms, identity, and even custom functions powered by AWS Lambda. And all this functionality can be configured directly in your repo.
